name: Dreaming Sarah
description: Dreaming Sarah is an adventure platformer where you play as Sarah, a girl who is in a coma. Explore the world around her and help her wake up!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: Intel Core 2 Duo Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: Intel HD Graphics 4000 or better DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 200 MB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 8 Processor: Intel Core i5 Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Nvidia GeForce 210 or higher DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 200 MB available space

reviews.review_text: A very atmospheric metroidvania-lite / exploration game. It's basically Yume Nikki in 2D, that's reason enough to love it.  EDIT: I'm an idiot. By Yume Nikki in 2D i mean sidescrolling as opposed to RPGMakeresque top-down view. Yume Nikki 3D is a thing though. I think. Or maybe i dreamed that.

I played this offline in early access, so my playtime should be closer to 2.5 hours or so, but this still is a fairly short game all the same. Typically I don't really like such short games. A few hours can't possibly be enough time to really get a satisfying experience, right? This is more or less the only gripe I have with the game, though. I just wish there was  more.  It's a charming platformer with creative worlds to explore and nice atmospheric music to really suck you into this strange little land. (Oh, and a copy of the OST comes free with the game!) There are some bugs here and there, but I personally didn't run into anything gamebreaking, so I can't say I was too put-off on that front. Even then, the dev has been in the forums working to fix things as people report them, so with any luck that point will be resolved with time. As an inexpensive game that clearly has so much love put into it, I'd say despite the short hours it lasted, it was 100% worth the money I spent on it.

I really love this game. It was really fun to play, It took awhile to understand what you should do but you'll get it eventually.   You play as Sarah that seems to have a really interesting and adventures dream. You gonna explore a lot of things.   I really recommend this game if you like platform games and adventure.  I won't tell you more, just get the game and play it already. I'm sure you'll like it.   + Great music + Good story  + Adventures   10/10
'All that we see or seem Is but a dream within a dream.'  Edgar Allan Poe  A quietly wonderful game, perfect for a rainy afternoon.

For a game relative to walk around solving puzzles and ways to advance further on into it was for sure a neat concept. I absolutely loved the nice graphics and musical atmosphere to this game. If you recommend ways to explore around, collecting items to advance further with no enemies but certain obstacles to get over and having certain messages that triggers it and such, this is the game for you. Secret areas included.

This game is extremely short. That is not a complaint from me because I normally do not have the time to beat very long video games. This game is strange. It's weird. But it is strange and weird in the best possible way. It didn't take me long to beat, and you really don't need the walkthrough (unless you want to make sure you get the secret achievements :D) to beat it. It doesn't go completely fullscreen, so a potato like my computer can run it. The art style is cute, and the world looks like something that would DEFINITELY occur in a dream. I highly reccomend it.
If you want a break from fast paced action, this is something to try. :D

It's a beautiful game, with great music and beautiful done pixel art.  Indeed feels like being in a strange dream. With lots of places to explore, some almost normal, some eerie, some just plain weird and some even slightly disturbing. There's some plataforming, some puzzles, items to use to reach new places, characters to meet, and lots of surreal exploring.  For anyone who liked Yume Nikki is a must. For anyone that like surreal games, too. And for anyone who like exploration games, give the game a try.  Great game.
Fun quirky weird platformer.  If you like patformers grab the game on sale.

You'll wander around the mind of a girl and get lost constantly.   Atmosphere is indeed dreamy and actually i felt like in one of my own dreams, since each part becomes available afterwards with its shortcut.  You'll discover the plot along the way.  It is an easy-to-play and a short game, but it's fun and satisfying.

This game is nice, just don't expect too much from it. Also it is very short, so getting it on sale would be the wisest move.  The story is about a girl who's apparently journeying around her subconcious. It may seem incoherent at first, but the game keeps giving you subtle hints. And all remaining questions are answered by an image after the ending credits.  The gameplay is relaxed and casual, closer to a 'walking simulator' rather than an actual platformer. There are some easy 'puzzles' and obvious 'secrets', which are more of an addition to the trippy atmosphere rather than a challenge-provider of any sort.  All in all, for me the game left a dreamy and serene aftertaste, so I can definitely recommend it. I especially liked the soundtrack, which is a decent example of the ambient genre - the devs appear to be artists indeed. What's more, it comes free as an album - another thanks for that.

Dreaming Sarah is an adventure/exploration game that is short enough to play in an evening while simultaneously delivering a fragmented (but by no means boring) storyline highly up for interpretation. Inspired by Japanese psychological/horror indie game Yume Nikki, it has a similar feel. Other than the obvious being that they are both exploration games taking place in a dream world, both have surreal music, at times disturbing art choices in character design, and a female protagonist with no dialogue. Also, both have artifact collection, with the game ending basically when you finish collecting all of them.  Whereas I enjoyed this game, I did feel as though it was just a lighter, more simplified, version of Yume Nikki in a lot of ways. Although they share many characteristics, Dreaming Sarah lacked the same amount of depth, and did not do much in adding to the genre.   That being said, the creator is upfront about it being a major source of inspiration for him, and there is at least one easter egg of Madotsuki's shirt's symbol on a bulletin board in one of the locations (there might be more, but I was giddy to find this one).   For the price it's being sold at, I would recommend this game. It's fun, doesn't have any boring tutorials, and most of all is an experience in surrealism that toys with your psyche.    Pros:  - Gameplay was simple and easy to get into - Puzzles/exploration wasn't too dumbed down - Character and level designs were interesting - Good music  Cons: - Didn't add anything to the genre - A little glitchy

We dream every night, regardless if we remember it or not.   Dreams are an important part of who we are. It is through them that we solve daily problems, face our fears and, sometimes, come to understand ourselves.   Dreaming Sarah  accomplishes exactly that: in a pixelated and rich platforming scenario we dwell into Sarah's mind to find out what exactly is bothering her. But it isn't as simple as that. The story starts off unassuming, mascarading itself as just another adventure platformer with nothing new to add to the genre. That's just meant to fool you, for as the story develops one is quick to grasp that, just like dreams, the game offers so much more behind what can be seen at first.  The game is creative and confusing, eye catching and trippy – all whilst maintaining coherence between Sarah, 'random' NPCs and inventory items. You will never get to know Sarah just by looking at what she does or the little she herself sometimes reveals. Her dreams scream of her identity, what she caries of her needs and desires, and who she envisions in her dreams of her past, her fears and her story.  All in all this is a solid indie game that leaves a short but sweet note at what dreams are, who we are in them and what one can be willing to see in if one looks deep enough – and there is hardly anything deeper that one's subconscious mind.  I recommend this game for the  good story ,  well done platforming ,  interesting NPCs ,  disturbing sights  and  meaningful details .  I don't think the  short length  or the  unremarkable music  are big enough downsides to stop anyone from playing this, even more so when the first one is more of an upside than downside and the second one is not the focus of the game.  As much attention as this game is getting, I'm of the firm conviction that it deserves even more.

It took me a little while longer to beat the game than most others here, but this is a great game! I loved playing every second of it. The music is beautiful and the game itself does a great job at portraying a story when it's mostly pictures. I recommend this to anyone who has the extra money and would like a short game to play while waiting or for passing time!

Dreaming Sarah is unfortunately a disappointment. The visuals and music are both quite pleasing, but they're attached to an essentially mediocre puzzle platformer. The puzzles themselves are generally simple to solve, but are throttled by tedious back-tracking and slow-paced exploration. The platforming itself is a chore with no challenge. At under 2 hours for completing all achievements, there isn't a whole lot here, but unfortunately by the end it already felt too long. Most of that time was spent running back and forth through the same areas, which lost much of their charm in the process. There are shortcuts revealed throughout, as well as an item that can teleport you back to the start, but even with that, traversing the small map areas becomes tedious. There's not much story to get involved in; the dibs and drabs of text that come out are largely disjointed and don't form any sort of narrative. Given that the game is a dream sequence that could be forgiven; if there were more to the game itself then the lack of story or character development wouldn't be an issue. Some older reviews mentioned technical issues. I didn't find any in my play through. I would like to point out that there is an umbrella in the game that lets you float around, which is needed for some puzzles but can be used everywhere. It's a pretty enjoyable enjoyable mechanic, and jumping and floating through each stage is the one nice break from the tedium.  As I said before, the art and sound are both nice, and are what initially got me to make the purchase. But nice visual design and soundtrack can't make up for the flaws in the actual game. I bought it on sale for under $3, but unfortunately even if it were free I would have been displeased, as the time spent was not really worth it.
Hey, Sarah is best girl. Best game ever!!
Dreaming Sarah was a very interesting game. There were a few points I didn't know what to do moving forward but overall it was a lot of fun. Very well made game.
A short, cheap and simple game, but totaly worth it!! Full functional commands and a nice story .
IN LOVE S2 SO SIMPLE AND SO CUTE S2 The pixel moves are wonderfuly !  Yume Nikki feelings~
A lot of back tracking. Quite annoying.
This is just random nonsense. You just have to explore the world in a semi-linear order and hope for it to end.

Since I am a huge sucker for Yume Nikki and the YN fangames, it was a must to get this game. It really gives the YN feels as I awaited and I'm not disappointed at all!  Pro: Nice settings Awesome music Good puzzles  Con: The controls like to eff up  But all together if you loved Yume Nikki, I recommend it!

Rally fun game to play, half of the time I didn't even know what was going on, but it was definetly fun. The only contra is the length of the game. Some people may fidn it short, but for me it was perfect, nice graphs nice music, good atmosphere, lot of WTF moments. >The Creators Used Some Kind Of Hallucinogens For Sure<

From the music to the smokey ambiance, Dreaming Sarah is one of those games that manages to find common ground and really draw the audience in. To anyone who ever played Earthbound/Mother 2, you'll know exactly what I'm talking about.

I originally bought the game for it's seemingly interesting storyline, and boy, was it worth it! The artstyle, soundtrack and general quirkiness of the game always kept it fresh and interesting and I was never bored while playing. I don't know if I'm the only one who's had this issue, but finishing the game was pretty difficult for me, since it doesn't really have any form of guidance (sometimes the compass will just not work outright, but that could also be caused by Sarah's coma) and the different areas can get confusing pretty quickly (I had to refer to a guide on Steam for the last couple achievements). Nevertheless, it was a great experience playing this game and I don't regret buying it. If I were a game critic, I'd probably give this game a rating of 7 or 7.5/10. Good job, Asteristic!

A really nice pixel game in which you play a girl who randomly wakes up in the middle of the forest: you have to 'just' go around and explore every world in order to find all the things that will help you reach the end and will help you understand the story of Sarah. If you liked Yumei Nikki you should like Dreaming Sarah too (don't worry, DS isn't creepy and scary as YM). The music is really nice and what's more there isn't a 'rigid' story but while you explore and find all the objects, you can interpret Sarah's story.  8/10

This is a very good game. At first, I thought it was just gonna be ok and it was on sale for like .59c so I figured I'd try it out. It definitley turned out being a lot better than I thought. It's definitley a great game.

A cool little artistic, surreal game. I think it was interesting and fun. Lots of easy-ish achievements :) Only one that didn't occur to me during my playthrough until I saw the name. I think it was a good use of a couple hours

In a nutshell: This game is a little gem!  I absolutely loved the simplicity of the game play and how intricate the design, the music and puzzles were. The creativity and imagination that went into the game are very intriguing. This is such an enchanting game with incredibly beautiful imaginative art and design work and a score that matches the game's somber mood perfectly.  Things to expect from this game: + lots of running around to explore and figure things out (I was stuck a lot and I admit, I had to google some things which I did not mind at all!) + Around 1-3 hours play time. + Very subtle, obscure humour (which I absolutely loved) + A linear story (you have to do XYZ or you won't progress) + beautiful, atmospheric score + incredibly imaginative art and design (possibly my favourite bit about this game!)  Fantastic indie game that works like a charm on the PC with an XBOX 360 controller.  What can I say? I bought this game on sale for literally nothing because I wanted to get back into gaming and the look of the game intrigued me. And I didn't expect much but as soon as I loaded the beginning sequence, I knew I would love this game and I really do.  I can only recommend it! :)

Short, minimalistic and beautiful. I'd pick it up on special to soften the length of the game, but definitely worth a look!   Ps. you can get the glasses on the first visit to the mansion (I would never have figured that out without a walkthrough, save yourself the effort...)

Dreaming Sarah is an excellent exploration game. The puzzles are mild and charming, although I was occasionally frustrated by the game's lack of direction. If you like exploration and have patience, Dreaming Sarah is fantastic. The environments made me feel like I was in a twisted, other dimension... kind of like a dream.

Fun and easy. Very casual. Even though I often felt lost, I eventually made it where I need to go. It's rather short, but the locations are unique & the music does a great job of setting the atmosphere. The graphics are smooth & soothing; for a game that could run on a potato. Satisfying game from start to finish, <3
Nice soundtrack. Nice gameplay. But too short and should have more story.  6/10 good game ;)

Probably not something you'd wanna pay full price for (I spent less than a dollar), but it's still a thumbs up for a lot of things. Nice music, cute art, smooth control (you be the judge of that), and it's a puzzle. Now, story wise, there's hardly anything being told and any characters you encounter has almost no depth, including Sarah herself, but if you were to get this, you may probably want to play this game for it's artstyle and puzzle and that's cool for me.  Mind you, if you try solving the puzzles without a walkthrough, be prepared to get lost for hours. But with a walkthrough, it probably would take about an hour or two to beat.
Very nice and beautiful game, albeit quite short. Has that feeling from Yume Nikki.

This game is short but sweet! An interesting platformer with an interesting dream world that sort of folds back in on itself as you play through. Reminds me of a light platformer version of Yume Nikki!
